metadata.title: CHOP and IRE1α-XBP1/JNK signaling promote Newcastle Disease Virus induced apoptosis and benefit virus proliferation

The XBP1 splicing was checked by RT-PCR using forward primer (Fig. 1C) . Therefore, PKR may contribute 340 to the activation eIF2α-ATF4-CHOP pathway during NDV infection.

CHOP promotes NDV-induced apoptosis by reducing the level of anti-apoptotic 342 protein BCL-2 and MCL-1 343 We have reported that NDV infection induces both intrinsic and extrinsic 344 apoptosis, and the extrinsic apoptosis is mediated by induction of death ligands, such 345 as TNF-α and TRAIL (44). Whether CHOP is involved in NDV-induced intrinsic 346 apoptosis? It has been known that CHOP promotes mitochondria mediated apoptosis 347 via down-regulation of the pro-survival BCL-2 family (24, 51). Thus, it will be 348 interesting to check whether the expression level of BCL-2 family is regulated by 349 NDV infection. Western blotting analysis showed that pro-survival BCL-2 and 350 MCL-1 were gradually decreased by 0 to 0.5-fold from 16 to 24 h.p.i in NDV-infected 351 HeLa cells ( Fig. 2A) . However, BCL-xL remained relatively stable along the infection 352 author/funder. All rights reserved. No reuse allowed without permission.

The copyright holder for this preprint (which was not peer-reviewed) is the . https://doi.org/10.1101/300129 doi: bioRxiv preprint time course ( Fig. 2A) . Moreover, the pro-apoptotic BH3 only proteins BIM and PUMA, the pore forming protein BAX and BAK, kept in steady level ( Fig. 2A) . The To confirm above observation, we next adopted the transient overexpression 377 approach. A plasmid encoding the full-length human CHOP with Flag tag at the N 378 terminus was constructed. HeLa cells were transfected with the construct or vector 379 control (PXJ40F) for 24 h before being infected with NDV for 16 h. As shown in Fig.   380 2D, the successful expression of Flag-CHOP was detected with Western blotting using 381 author/funder. All rights reserved. No reuse allowed without permission.

The copyright holder for this preprint (which was not peer-reviewed) is the . https://doi.org/10.1101/300129 doi: bioRxiv preprint of CHOP reduced the level of MCL-1 by 0.7-fold and BCL-2 by 0.2-fold, respectively.

As expected, overexpression of CHOP promoted PARP cleavage by 3.1-fold. 384 Meanwhile, the expression of viral protein NP was increased by 1.9-fold in CHOP 385 transfected cells (Fig. 2D) . Furthermore, the virus yield in culture medium was also 386 increased (Fig. 2E ). The experiment was performed multiple times and reproducible.

Taken together, these data further demonstrate that CHOP promotes apoptosis via 388 down-regulation of BCL-2 and MCL-1, and helps NDV proliferation. The copyright holder for this preprint (which was not peer-reviewed) is the . https://doi.org/10.1101/300129 doi: bioRxiv preprint phospho-JNK (34.5-to 120-fold) and phospho-p38 (1.7-to 23.9-fold) at 12-24 h.p.i. 411 were detected in NDV-infected cells, both of which were almost undetectable in 412 mock-infected cells. Above results reveals that NDV infection moderately activates 413 pro-survival AKT and ERK1/2, and greatly stimulates pro-apoptotic JNK and p38 414 signaling at late infection stage.

To study whether CHOP is involved in regulation of above signaling cascades, 416 CHOP was either knocked down or overexpressed in HeLa cells, followed by NDV in NDV-induced apoptosis and virus proliferation, we used siRNA to specifically 517 knock down XBP1 in HeLa cells, followed with NDV infection. As expected, the 518 expression of XBP1s was successfully knocked down by siXBP1, and XBP1u was 519 moderately decreased (Fig. 5H) . Interestingly, transfection of siXBP1 resulted in 520 0.5-fold decrease of NP synthesis, compared to those in sic transfected cells (Fig. 5H ). 521 author/funder. All rights reserved. No reuse allowed without permission.

The copyright holder for this preprint (which was not peer-reviewed) is the . https://doi.org/10.1101/300129 doi: bioRxiv preprint In addition to mediating XBP1 mRNA splicing, IRE1α also recruits TRAF2 and 530 ASK1, subsequently activating MKK4/7 and JNK (68). JNK promotes apoptosis 531 either by directly regulating the apoptotic proteins activity or activating the 532 transcription factor for pro-apoptotic protein (69). We have shown that JNK was 533 phosphorylated at late stage of NDV infection (Fig. 3A) , and CHOP promotes this 534 activation (Fig. 3B, 3C) . We next asked whether IRE1α was involved in NDV-induced 535 JNK activation. HeLa cells were transfected with siIRE1α or sic before being infected 536 with NDV, and the phosphorylation level of JNK was examined by Western blotting. (Fig. 6D) . Accordingly, in SP600125 558 treated cells, NP mRNA was also greatly decreased, compared to that in 559 DMSO-treated cells (Fig. 6E) . Meanwhile, inhibition of JNK kinase activity reduced 560 the cleavage of PARP by 0.7-fold (Fig. 6D) . Moreover, the transcription of death 561 ligand TNF-α and cytokines IFN-β, IL-6, IL-8 was markedly suppressed in SP600125 562 treated cells, as evidenced by semi-quantitative real time RT-PCR (Fig. 6E) . To 563 validate above results, specifically knock down of JNK by siRNA was performed. As 564 shown in Fig. 6F , JNK was successfully depleted by siJNK (0.05-fold), which 565 significantly reduced the level of viral NP expression (0.3-fold), compared to that in 566 sic control cells. PARP cleavage was also greatly decreased by 0.3-fold (Fig. 6F ).

Accordingly, NP, TNF-α, IL-6 and IL-8 mRNA was also suppressed by in JNK 568 depletion cells (Fig. 6G ). Collectively, above results demonstrate that activation of 569 JNK promotes virus proliferation and virus-induced apoptosis/inflammation.

The PCR product was digested with Hind III 225 and Xba I restriction enzymes, and cloned into vector p3ⅹFlag-CMV-14. For 226 construction of pCMV-XBP1s plasmid, full length XBP1s (NM_001079539.1) was 227 amplified by PCR from human cDNA using the forward primer 228 5'-GCAATCAAGCTTATGGTGGTGGTGGCAGCCG-3' and reverse primer 229 5'-GACGTGTCTAGAGACACTAATCAGCTGGGGAAAGAG-3'. The PCR product 230 was digested with the restriction enzyme Pst I to remove the XBP1u fragment, 231 followed with Hind III and Xba I digestion, finally cloned into vector 232 p3ⅹFlag-CMV-14. 233 Transfection of plasmids and siRNAs 234 HeLa cells were transfected with plasmids or siRNAs using lipofectamine 2000 Total RNA was extracted using TRIzol ® Reagent (Invitrogen，USA) according to 273 the manufacturer's instructions. Briefly, cells were lysed with TRIzol and the lysates 274 were mixed with one-fifth volume of chloroform. After centrifugation at 12000×g at 275 4°C for 15 min, the aqueous phase was mixed with an equal volume of isopropanol.276 RNA was pelleted by centrifugation at 12000×g at 4°C for 20 min, washed with 70% 277 ethanol twice, and dissolved in RNase-free H 2 O. The concentration of the RNA was 278 measured using a NanoDrop 2000 spectrophotometer (Thermo Fisher Scientific, 279 USA).280 cDNA was reversed transcribed from total RNA using expand reverse 281 transcriptase (Roche, USA) and oligo-dT primer. Equal volume of cDNA was 282 PCR-amplified using SYBR Green qPCR Mix in a CFX96TM real-time PCR system 283 (Bio-Rad, USA). Primers used for amplify β-actin, NP, IRE1, XBP1u, XBP1s, P58 IPK , 284 ERdj4, EDEM1, IFN-β, TNF-α, IL-6 and IL-8 were listed in table 2. The mRNA 285 levels of specific genes were calculated using β-actin as an internal reference and 286

FIGREF2.text: in mitochondria outer membranes, initiating apoptosis. To investigate the 356 role of CHOP in regulation of BCL-2 and MCL-1 level during NDV infection, we 357 used siRNA (siCHOP) to specifically knock down CHOP in HeLa cells. Cells were 358 transfected with siCHOP or non-targeting control siRNA (sic), followed with NDV 359 infection at 36 h post-transfection, and subjected to Western blot analysis at 16 h.p.i..

FIGREF3.text: As expected, compared to sic transfected control group, siCHOP efficiently knocked361 down the NDV-induced expression of CHOP (Fig. 2B). As expected, knock down of 362 CHOP increased the level of MCL-1 and BCL-2 by 2.6-fold and 1.1-fold, respectively 363 (Fig. 2B). Cleavage of poly ADP-ribose polymerase (PARP), a substrate of caspase-3, 364 from the 116-kDa full length protein (PARP-FL) to an 85-kDa inactive polypeptide 365 (PARP-C), was used here as a major biochemical marker of apoptosis. As shown in 366 Fig. 2B, a significant amount of the PARP cleavage product was detected in 367 NDV-infected control group; in contrast, less PARP cleavage (0.6-fold) was observed 368 in NDV-infected CHOP knock down cells. Above results substantiates the hypothesis 369 that CHOP plays a pro-apoptotic role in NDV-infected cells, probably through 370 regulation of MCL-1 and BCL-2 level. Surprisingly, viral NP expression level was 371 reduced by 0.4-fold in CHOP knock down cells compared to that in control cells (Fig. 372 2B). Accordingly, the release of virus progeny was greatly reduced, as determined by 373 TCID 50 assay (Fig. 2C). The experiment was performed multiple times and 374 reproducible. Above results demonstrate that virus proliferation is moderately 375 suppressed in CHOP knock down cells.

FIGREF5.text: 389CHOP promotes apoptosis by regulation of AKT and JNK/p38 signaling390 cascades 391 MAPK cascades play a critical role in regulation of cell growth, differentiation, 392 and control of cellular responses to cytokines and stress (52, 53). ERK1/2 is activated 393 by growth and neurotrophic factors (54-56); JNK and p38 MAPK are activated by 394 inflammatory cytokines and by a wide variety of cellular stresses (57, 58). AKT 395 plays a critical role in promoting cell survival by inhibiting apoptosis (59), through 396 phosphorylation and inactivation of several targets, including Bad (60), forkhead 397 transcription factors (61), c-Raf (62), and caspase 9 (63). To check whether MAPK 398 and AKT pathways are involved in NDV-induced apoptosis, the kinetic activation of 399 these kinases during NDV infection was examined by Western blotting analysis. As 400 shown in Fig. 3A, AKT was phosphorylated from 4 to 24 h.p.i. in both mock-and 401 NDV-infected cells, compared to that at 0 h.p.i.. This might be due to stimulation of 402 AKT signaling by removing serum during infection. It was noted that the level of 403 phospho-AKT in NDV-infected cells was higher by 2.8-to 10.3-fold than that in 404 mock-infected cells at 16-24 h.p.i., suggesting the virus infection moderately 405 stimulates AKT signaling at late infection stage. The level of phospho-ERK1/2 was 406 also increased from 4 to 24 h.p.i. in both mock-and NDV-infected cells, compared to 407 that at 0 h.p.i.. Also, the level of phospho-ERK1/2 in NDV-infected cells was higher 408 than that in mock-infected cells at 12-24 h.p.i., indicating the virus infection 409 author/funder. All rights reserved. No reuse allowed without permission.

FIGREF6.text: 417infection. As shown inFig. 3Band 3C, knock down of CHOP slightly increased the XBP1s protein as nuclear transcription factor, and initiates the transcription of ER 498 chaperones and ERAD components.499 XBP1 is essential for efficient NDV replication 500 In order to maintain the homeostasis of the ER under stress, XBP1s induces the 501 expression of ER chaperones and ERAD components, thereby enhancing the capacity 502 of productive folding and degradation mechanism (12, 66). It is also reported that 503 XBP1u and XBP1s is involved in IBV induced apoptosis (27). XBP1-dificient cells 504 were resistant to apoptosis induced by vesicular stomatitis virus (VSV) and herpes 505 simplex virus (HSV) infection (67). These reports indicate that XBP1 is involved in 506 cell fate determination during virus infection. To study the role of XBP1u and XBP1s 507 in NDV-induced apoptosis, we first adopted the overexpression approach. The coding 508 sequence of XBP1u or XBP1s was inserted into pCMV vector respectively, with Flag 509 tag at C-terminus. HeLa cells were transfected with construct XBP1u, XBP1s, or 510 pCMV vector, followed with NDV infection. Using anti-Flag antibody, the expression 511 of both proteins was clearly detectable (Fig. 5G). Compared with the vector control, 512 in cells transfected with XBP1u, slightly lower level of NDV NP (0.9-fold) and 513 NDV-induced PARP cleavage (0.9-fold) could be detected. In contrast, in cells 514 transfected with XBP1s, the level NDV NP and NDV-induced PARP cleavage was 515 similar to that in vector control (Fig. 5G). To further investigate the function of XBP1516

FIGREF7.text: virus proliferation and virus induced apoptosis, the knock down experiment 525 demonstrates that XBP1 is necessary for efficient NDV replication and NDV-induced 526 apoptosis. However, it is difficult to attribute the observed phenotype to individual 527 isoforms as siXBP1 targets both XBP1u and XBP1s. 528 NDV infection activates pro-apoptotic JNK via IRE1α and NF-κB 529

FIGREF8.text: As shown in Fig. 6A, knock down of IRE1α greatly reduced the phosphorylation of 538 JNK by 0.2-fold, compared with that in sic control cells. In contrast, in cells 539 transfected with plasmid encoding IRE1α, the NDV-induced phosphorylation of JNK 540 was greatly increased by 2.2-fold, compared to that in vector transfected cells (Fig. 541 IKK16 did not change the expression of NDV NP protein; however, it reduced the 550 phospho-JNK to minimum level (0.1-fold), compared to that in the control cells. This 551 result suggests that JNK is not only activated by IRE1α, but also stimulated via 552 NF-κB-TNF-α signaling. Thus, activation of JNK is controlled by multiple signaling 553 during NDV infection. 554 To explore the role of JNK in NDV-induced apoptosis, JNK kinase activity was 555 inhibited by SP600125 (7.5 μM) after NDV infection. Western blotting results showed 556 that SP600125 treatment really inhibited the phosphorylation of JNK by 0.3-fold, and 557 decreased NDV NP expression by 0.7-fold

FIGREF9.text: infection, many viral proteins are synthesized by ER-associated 572 ribosome and transported into ER lumen for proper folding or post-translational 573 modification. This leads to an overwhelming load of unfolded or misfolded proteins 574 in ER lumen. Then, chaperone Bip binds to these unfolded/misfolded proteins and 575 releases ER stress sensors PERK, ATF6, IRE1α, triggering UPR, marked as protein 576 translation shut down, activation of transcription factors (ATF4, ATF6, XBP1s), protect cells from virus induced cytopathic effects (73); Hepatitis C virus 581 protein NS4B activates IRE1α to protect the infected cells from apoptosis, facilitating 582 the development of chronic infection and hepatocellular carcinoma (67); Reovirus 583 induces the phosphorylation of eIF2α and expression of ATF4, which activates the 584 integrated stress response and promotes survival of stressed cells, benefiting virus 585 replication (74); Classical swine fever virus (CSFV) activates IRE1-XBP1-GRP78 586 signal and maintains ER homeostasis, to promote its replication (75); Herpes simplex 587 virus 1 (HSV-1) can flee from cellular responses that are likely detrimental to viral 588 replication via suppressing the IRE1-XBP1 branch by tegument protein UL41 (76). 589 Whether similar mechanisms are applied to NDV infection remains to be investigated 590 As an acute infection pathogen and oncolytic reagent, NDV induces apoptosis as 591 a major hallmark in host cells and several tumor cell lines. However, whether UPR is 592 involved in NDV-induced apoptosis has not been well characterized. Previous studies 593 have shown that NDV infection activates PKR and promotes phosphorylation of

FIGREF10.text: NDV infection induces the expression of transcription factor CHOP. (A) 666 Induction of CHOP by NDV infection. HeLa cells were infected with NDV and 667 harvested at 0, 4, 8, 12, 16, 20, and 24 h.p.i.. The cell lysates were analyzed by 668 Western blotting with antibodies against CHOP and NDV NP protein. β-actin was 669 detected as a loading control. The intensity of CHOP band was determined by Image J 670 software and normalized to β-actin, respectively, and shown as fold change of NDV 671 (+ : -). (B) Nuclear translocation of CHOP during NDV infection. HeLa cells were 672 infected with NDV and subjected to immunofluorescence at 16 h.p.i., using antibodies 673 against CHOP and NP. The signal of CHOP and viral protein NP were observed under 674 confocal microscope. (C) CHOP is induced by PKR-eIF2α signaling. HeLa cells were 675 infected with NDV and treated with 10 μM of GSK2606414 (GSK), and harvested at 676 16 h.p.i.. DMSO treatment was included as control in a parallel experiment. The 677 phospho-eIF2α, CHOP, NP, and β-actin were analyzed with Western blotting. The 678 intensity of phospho-eIF2α and CHOP band was determined, normalized to eIF2α or 679 β-actin respectively, and shown as fold change of GSK (+ : -).

TABREF0.text: shown). Thus, NDV infection greatly induces the expression of CHOP in time dependent manner and promotes its nuclear translocation. The persistent exposure to the NDV infection results in pro-apoptotic transcription factor expression and may promote apoptotic death.During our previous study, we found that PERK was cleaved and PKR was responsible for the eIF2α phosphorylation and GADD34 induction during NDVinfection (45). To clarify whether PERK-eIF2α or PKR-eIF2α signaling is involved in NDV-induced CHOP expression, HeLa cells were treated with GSK2606414, an inhibitor blocks PERK activity at low dose (IC 50 : 0.4 nM) and blocks PKR activity at high dose (IC 50 : 696 nM) (50). In our previous report, we have demonstrated that GSK2606414 did not decrease the phosphorylation level of eIF2α at the low dose of 335 inhibiting PERK(45). Thus, PKR may be responsible for phosphorylation of eIF2α and CHOP induction. Thus, we treated NDV-infected HeLa cells with 10 μM of GSK2606414, a dose suppressing PKR activity. Western blotting results showed this dose of inhibitor greatly reduced phospho-eIF2α by 0.1-fold and decreased CHOP by 339 0.2-fold, compared to DMSO-treated group
